name: market for fatty alcohol sulfate | fatty alcohol sulfate | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/17843/documentation

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.;This is the market for  'fatty alcohol sulfate', in the Global geography.;In this market, expert judgement was used to develop product specific transport distance estimations.;fatty alcohol sulfate' represents an organic substance. The compounds consists of a sulfate group with an aliphatic chain and the molecular formula is: CH3(CH2)nOSO3, whereas n can vary between 10 and 21. The compounds are mostly liquid under normal conditions of temperature and pressure. It is modelled as a pure substance.  On a consumer level, they are used in the following products: detergents and surfactants. On industrial sites, these substances are used for the manufacture of products in the following sectors: chemicals.

This activity starts at the gate of the activities that produce 'fatty alcohol sulfate',  within the geography of Global.

This activity ends with the supply of 'fatty alcohol sulfate',  to the consumers of this product. Transport is included. Product losses during transportation are assumed negligible and are therefore not included.

exchanges.description:
The total marine transport volume differentiated into major commodity groups based on data from FearnResearch (2001): Fearnley's Annual Review 2000. Oslo: Fearnley/AS, p. 1-78. The category “Other cargo” accounts for 38% of total maritime transport volume and has been distributed on commodity groups based on the proportions of transport by rail and inland waterways.
The total marine transport volume differentiated into major commodity groups based on data from FearnResearch (2001): Fearnley's Annual Review 2000. Oslo: Fearnley/AS, p. 1-78. The category “Other cargo” accounts for 38% of total maritime transport volume and has been distributed on commodity groups based on the proportions in the marine import and export of the US in 2001-2010.
